elements.content: To achieve reversible photoswitching of the magnetic properties of single-molecule magnets (SMMs), coordination assemblies of a mixed valence tetranuclear [MnII 2MnIII 2] complex linked by open- and closed-ring isomers of a photochromic diarylethene ligand were synthesized: [Mn4(hmp)6(dae-o)2(ClO4)2]·6H2O (open-ring form; 1o) and [Mn4(hmp)6(dae-c)2(H2O)2](ClO4)2·CH3CN·4H2O (closed-ring form; 1c), where Hhmp is 2-hydroxymethylpyridine, and H2dae-o and H2dae-c are open- and closed-ring isomers of 1,2-bis(5-caxboxyl-2-methyl-3-thienyl)perfluorocyclopentene (H2dae), respectively. From X-ray crystallographic analyses, 1o and 1c have one-dimensional (1-D) chain structures with a repeating unit of [−{Mn4}−(dae)−], in which the [Mn4] units are bridged by the diarylethene ligands coordinated to the MnII sites via carboxylate groups. Magnetic measurements involving direct-current (dc) and alternating-current (ac) techniques showed that each [Mn4] cluster in the 1-D chains had an S T = 9 ground state due to two kinds of intracluster ferromagnetic exchange interactions and behaved as SMMs. Both 1o and 1c underwent photochromic reactions in the crystalline phase, and their colors reversibly changed between reddish-brown and blue upon irradiation with ultraviolet (UV) and visible light. For 1o, no significant change in the magnetic properties was observed after the photocyclization of the dae-o moiety by UV irradiation. In contrast, the photocycloreversion of the dae-c moiety by visible irradiation enhanced inter-[Mn4] unit interactions in 1c, which was triggered by the geometrical change in the diarylethene moiety during the photoreaction and the subsequent change in the inter-[Mn4] arrangement between the neighboring 1-D chains. This work illustrates the usefulness of photochromic molecules for photoswitching the magnetic behavior of complexes, even superparamagnetic systems, with SMM units.

elements.content: Single-molecule magnets (SMMs), which display slow relaxation of the magnetization and therefore behave as nanosized magnets below blocking temperatures (T B), have attracted much attention in a wide area of science including chemistry and physics. The relaxation dynamics of the magnetization has been attributed to the intrinsic properties of a molecule, such as a large easy-axis-type magnetoanisotropy (negative zero-field splitting parameter: D < 0) and a large spin ground state (S T), resulting in an energy barrier (Δ) of |D|S T 2 for integer spins and |D|(S T 2 − 1/4) for half-integer spins between spin-up and spin-down configurations, m s = ±S T. Extensive research has been performed to prepare new SMMs and to understand their magnetic properties from the viewpoints of fundamental science, such as the possibility of bridging classical and quantum regimes, and potential applications in new devices, such as single-molecule magnetic memory devices as bits due to their nanometer-scale uniform sizes and quantum computers due to quantum tunneling of the magnetization (QTM).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Single-molecule magnets (SMMs), which display slow relaxation of the magnetization and therefore behave as nanosized magnets below blocking temperatures (T B), have attracted much attention in a wide area of science including chemistry and physics. The relaxation dynamics of the magnetization has been attributed to the intrinsic properties of a molecule, such as a large easy-axis-type magnetoanisotropy (negative zero-field splitting parameter: D < 0) and a large spin ground state (S T), resulting in an energy barrier (Δ) of |D|S T 2 for integer spins and |D|(S T 2 - 1/4) for half-integer spins between spin-up and spin-down configurations, m s = ±S T. Extensive research has been performed to prepare new SMMs and to understand their magnetic properties from the viewpoints of fundamental science, such as the possibility of bridging classical and quantum regimes, and potential applications in new devices, such as single-molecule magnetic memory devices as bits due to their nanometer-scale uniform sizes and quantum computers due to quantum tunneling of the magnetization (QTM).

elements.content: As the next step in this research field, the design of SMMs of which the magnetic properties can be reversibly switched by applying external stimuli is important and would bring about new applications for SMMs. Light should be a powerful tool for switching systems because the switching behavior can be controlled precisely in a wide range of the resolutions of time and space. Herein, we present a reversible photoswitching system involving 1-D chain coordination assemblies comprised of SMMs and photochromic molecules (Scheme ). The photochromic molecules not only undergo a reversible color change but also change other chemical and physical properties upon photoisomerization. Various photochromic compounds have been synthesized and investigated for application in molecular memory and switching devices. We chose a photochromic diarylethene ligand, dae2−, which had two carboxylate groups at 5-positions on thiophene rings as shown in Scheme a (dae2− stands for the deprotonated dianion of 1,2-bis(5-caxboxyl-2-methyl-3-thienyl)perfluorocyclopentene (H2dae), and dae-o2− and dae-c2− are open and closed-ring isomers, respectively) to act as a photoswitch and cluster linkages. dae2− reversibly isomerizes between open- and closed-ring isomers when irradiated with UV and visible light via 6π electrocyclic reactions of the 1,3,5-hexatriene moieties in the molecules. A remarkable feature of the diarylethene derivatives is that they show thermally stable and fatigue-resistant photochromic performance not only in solution but also in the single-crystalline phase. Several examples involving the photoswitching of single-molecule fluorescence and conductivity via the photochromic reaction of diarylethene ligand have been reported. Using the diarylethene groups to bridge the SMMs should bring about the following for the photoreversible modulation of magnetic properties: (I) direct switching of superexchange interactions through the π-system of the diarylethene (Scheme a) and (II) indirect switching of through-space interactions between SMM units due to structural changes (Scheme b). In the case of direct switching, the structure of the π-system of the open- and closed-ring isomers is different. The π-conjugation of the two thiophene rings are separated in the open-ring isomer, whereas it is expanded over the entire molecule in the closed-ring isomer. Therefore, the photoreversible change in π-conjugation of the diarylethene moiety should cause a change in the superexchange interactions between the combined SMM units (intrachain switching; Scheme a), resulting in dynamic photoswitching behavior via an “exchange-bias” effect on the magnetization relaxation of the SMM unit. As a representative example for this case, photoswitching of the magnetic interactions between two nitronyl nitroxide radicals bridged by diarylethene molecules has been reported. Indirect switching should occur when the geometrical structures reversibly change upon photochromic reaction, as X-ray crystallographic studies have shown. This change should cause the packing of the SMM chains to change, which would indirectly lead to the modulation of the through-space magnetic interactions (interchain switching; Scheme b).

Proposed Photoswitching Mechanisms in the Photochromic 1-D SMM Chains<xref rid="sch2-fn1"></xref>

(a) Direct switching of superexchange interactions due to the change in the π-system of the diarylethene ligand (intrachain switching) and (b) indirect switching of through-space interactions due to the change in the geometrical structure of the diarylethene ligand (interchain switching), where the arrows indicate the magnetization of SMM aligned on an easy axis; in the case of interacted systems of (a) and (b) with exchange couplings J, fustian antiferromagnetically coupled features were for instance illustrated.

elements.content: In this study, a double-cuboidal mixed valence [MnII 2MnIII 2] cluster was used as the SMM unit (Scheme b). The prototype of the SMMs [Mn4(hmp)6Br2(H2O)2]Br2·4H2O (hmp−: deprotonated anion of 2-hydroxymethylpyridine, Hhmp), of which S T = 9, has been reported. This SMM is robust and acts as a coordination-acceptor building block for SMM networks without a significant change in the core structure. Using these units, we synthesized 1-D chain structures, in which the [Mn4] units were linked by the dae2− ligands in the open- and closed-ring forms: [Mn4(hmp)6(dae-o)2(ClO4)2]·6H2O (1o) and [Mn4(hmp)6(dae-c)2(H2O)2](ClO4)2·CH3CN·4H2O (1c), respectively (Scheme c). In this paper, we report the syntheses, crystal structures, and photochromic and magnetic properties of the 1-D SMM chains 1o and 1c. The effect of the photochromic reactions of the diarylethene ligand on the magnetic properties will also be discussed.

Using these units, we synthesized 1-D chain structures, in which the [Mn4] units were linked by the dae2- ligands in the open- and closed-ring forms: [Mn4(hmp)6(dae-o)2(ClO4)2]⋅6H2O (1o) and [Mn4(hmp)6(dae-c)2(H2O)2](ClO4)2⋅CH3CN⋅4H2O (1c), respectively (Scheme c). The effect of the photochromic reactions of the diarylethene ligand on the magnetic properties will also be discussed.

elements.content: There are two synthetic routes for preparing assemblies of the double-cuboidal [MnII 2MnIII 2] SMMs. One involves a one-pot reaction in which the formation of the SMM core and assembly via the bridging groups occur at the same time in a solution containing Mn sources, ligands for constructing the SMM core (hmp−), and the bridging ligand. The other route involves the assembly of the preisolated SMM unit with the bridging ligand. At the present time, 1-D, 2-D, and 3-D assemblies of the [Mn4] SMMs bridged by polydentate ligands, such as azide, chloride, dicyanamide, {Mn[N(CN)2]6}2−, and [Pt(nmt)2]− (mnt2− = maleonitriledithiolate), have been synthesized using the two methods. In the present study, the one-pot method was used, and the detailed procedure is described in the Experimental Section. Briefly, MnII(ClO4)2 as a Mn source was reacted with Hhmp in the presence of NEt4OH in acetonitrile to afford the [Mn4] core. Then, the protonated photochromic ligand H2dae-o or H2dae-c was added to the solution. Slow diffusion of another solvent into the resulting solution afforded black single crystals of 1o or 1c. Note that, during crystallization, everything must be kept in the dark, especially 1c.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

There are two synthetic routes for preparing assemblies of the double-cuboidal [MnII 2MnIII 2] SMMs. One involves a one-pot reaction in which the formation of the SMM core and assembly via the bridging groups occur at the same time in a solution containing Mn sources, ligands for constructing the SMM core (hmp-), and the bridging ligand. The other route involves the assembly of the preisolated SMM unit with the bridging ligand. At the present time, 1-D, 2-D, and 3-D assemblies of the [Mn4] SMMs bridged by polydentate ligands, such as azide, chloride, dicyanamide, {Mn[N(CN)2]6}2-, and [Pt(nmt)2]- (mnt2- = maleonitriledithiolate), have been synthesized using the two methods. In the present study, the one-pot method was used, and the detailed procedure is described in the Experimental Section. Briefly, MnII(ClO4)2 as a Mn source was reacted with Hhmp in the presence of NEt4OH in acetonitrile to afford the [Mn4] core. Then, the protonated photochromic ligand H2dae-o or H2dae-c was added to the solution. Slow diffusion of another solvent into the resulting solution afforded black single crystals of 1o or 1c. Note that, during crystallization, everything must be kept in the dark, especially 1c.

elements.content: Crystallographic data for 1o and 1c are listed in Table . 1o crystallized in the monoclinic space group C2/c with a C2 rotation axis on the dae-o2− ligand and an inversion center on the [Mn4] unit (Z = 4). 1o has an infinite 1-D chain structure, in which the [Mn4] units are bridged by the dae-o2− ligand to form an alternate arrangement [−{Mn4}−(dae-o)−], as shown in Figure a (the hexafluorocyclopentene ring in dae-o2− is disordered, as observed with other diarylethene derivatives ()). An ORTEP drawing of the repeating unit in the 1-D chain structure of 1o is shown in Figure b, and selected bond distances and angles in the [Mn4] core are listed in . The [Mn4] moiety has a typical double-cuboidal core containing two inner MnIII ions (Mn(2) and Mn(2)*) and two outer MnII ions (Mn(1) and Mn(1)*), which were assigned on the basis of bond valence sum (BVS) calculations, with six hmp− bidentate ligands, forming the basic [Mn4(hmp)6]4+ core. The core of 1c is similar (vide infra). The inner MnIII ions are hexacoordinated with an N2O4 atom set from the hmp− ligands, whereas the outer MnII ions are heptacoordinated with an NO3 atom set from the hmp− ligands, two O atoms from the carboxylate groups of dae-o2−, and one O atom from ClO4 − as a capping ligand. Thus, each carboxylate group of dae-o2− acts as a bidentate ligand to the outer MnII ion. The inner MnIII ions Mn(2) and Mn(2)* exhibit a Jahn−Teller distortion causing them to have an elongated tetragonal geometry with the axes along O(3)*−Mn(2)−N(2)* and O(3)−Mn(2)*−N(2), respectively (Mn(2)−N(2)* = 2.127(3) Å, Mn(2)−O(3)* = 2.118(3) Å, O(3)*−Mn(2)−N(2)* = 160.86(13)°), where the two Jahn−Teller axes are parallel to each other in the [Mn4] core because of the presence of the inversion center at the midpoint of the core.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 1o

Crystallographic data for 1o and 1c are listed in Table . 1o crystallized in the monoclinic space group C2/c with a C2 rotation axis on the dae-o2- ligand and an inversion center on the [Mn4] unit (Z = 4). 1o has an infinite 1-D chain structure, in which the [Mn4] units are bridged by the dae-o2- ligand to form an alternate arrangement [-{Mn4}-(dae-o)-], as shown in Figure a (the hexafluorocyclopentene ring in dae-o2- is disordered, as observed with other diarylethene derivatives ()). An ORTEP drawing of the repeating unit in the 1-D chain structure of 1o is shown in Figure b, and selected bond distances and angles in the [Mn4] core are listed in . The [Mn4] moiety has a typical double-cuboidal core containing two inner MnIII ions (Mn(2) and Mn(2)*) and two outer MnII ions (Mn(1) and Mn(1)*), which were assigned on the basis of bond valence sum (BVS) calculations, with six hmp- bidentate ligands, forming the basic [Mn4(hmp)6]4+ core. The core of 1c is similar (vide infra). The inner MnIII ions are hexacoordinated with an N2O4 atom set from the hmp- ligands, whereas the outer MnII ions are heptacoordinated with an NO3 atom set from the hmp- ligands, two O atoms from the carboxylate groups of dae-o2-, and one O atom from ClO4 - as a capping ligand. Thus, each carboxylate group of dae-o2- acts as a bidentate ligand to the outer MnII ion. The inner MnIII ions Mn(2) and Mn(2)* exhibit a Jahn-Teller distortion causing them to have an elongated tetragonal geometry with the axes along O(3)*-Mn(2)-N(2)* and O(3)-Mn(2)*-N(2), respectively (Mn(2)-N(2)* = 2.127(3) Å, Mn(2)-O(3)* = 2.118(3) Å, O(3)*-Mn(2)-N(2)* = 160.86(13)°), where the two Jahn-Teller axes are parallel to each other in the [Mn4] core because of the presence of the inversion center at the midpoint of the core.

elements.content: Since the main purpose in this work involves photochromic reactions in the solid state, we should discuss here the possibility of isomerization to the closed-ring isomer from a structural point of view. The photochromic reactivity of the diarylethene derivatives in the crystalline state strongly depends on the conformation of the molecules in the crystal. To undergo the photocylization reaction, the two thiophene rings of the diarylethene moiety must be fixed in an antiparallel conformation, and the distance between the reacting carbon atoms must be less than 4 Å. In 1o, the dae-o2− ligand has an antiparallel conformation, and the distance between the reacting carbon atoms (C(19)···C(19)**) was determined to be 3.371 Å (Figure b). Thus, the requirements for the photocyclization reaction are met.

The photochromic reactivity of the diarylethene derivatives in the crystalline state strongly depends on the conformation of the molecules in the crystal. To undergo the photocylization reaction, the two thiophene rings of the diarylethene moiety must be fixed in an antiparallel conformation, and the distance between the reacting carbon atoms must be less than 4 Å. In 1o, the dae-o2- ligand has an antiparallel conformation, and the distance between the reacting carbon atoms (C(19)⋅⋅⋅C(19)**) was determined to be 3.371 Å (Figure b). Thus, the requirements for the photocyclization reaction are met.

elements.content: Figure shows packing diagrams of 1o. The 1-D chain lies in the a+c direction in the crystal lattice. The neighboring chains are in an in-phase arrangement, making alternately stacked 2-D layers of the [Mn4] unit and the dae-o2− ligand (Figure a). The Jahn−Teller axes in the [Mn4] cores are also parallel to each other in the entire crystal. The interunit MnII···MnII distance in the chains across the dae-o2− ligand was determined to be 12.741 Å. The nearest interchain interunit distance was found to be 8.453 Å for MnII···MnIII (Figure b).

elements.content: 1c crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/m with an inversion center on the [Mn4] moiety and a mirror plane through the dae-c2− ligand (Z = 2; Table ). Similar to 1o, 1c has an infinite 1-D chain structure composed of [Mn4] double-cuboidal units and the dae-c2− ligands in an alternating arrangement [−{Mn4}−(dae-c)−] (Figure a), in which the dae-c2− ligand acts as a bidentate ligand coordinating to the outer Mn sites of the [Mn4] unit via carboxylate groups. The (R,R) and (S,S) enantiomers of dae-c2− were disordered because they sit in the same site with an occupancy ratio of 1:1, and the hexafluorocyclopentene ring of dae-c2− was also disordered similar to that of 1o (). An ORTEP drawing of the repeating unit in the 1-D chain of 1c is shown in Figure b, and selected bond distances and angles in the [Mn4] core are listed in . The [Mn4] moiety has a [Mn4(hmp)6]4+ core. The outer and inner Mn ions were assigned to be MnII and MnIII on the basis of bond valence sum (BVS) calculations and structural characteristics (vide infra). As in the case of 1o, the inner MnIII ions are hexacoordinated, and the outer MnII ions are heptacoordinated. However, the terminal ligand on the MnII ion is a water molecule instead of ClO4 − which is the terminal ligand in 1o. The ClO4 − ions are located between chains. The two MnIII ions exhibited Jahn−Teller elongation of the O(3)*−Mn(2)−N(2)* and O(3)−Mn(2)*−N(2) axes with Mn(2)−N(2)* = 2.220(5) Å, Mn(2)−O(3)* = 2.280(3) Å, and O(3)*−Mn(2)−N(2)* = 161.19(18)°. The two Jahn−Teller axes were parallel to each other in the core. As we can see in Figure b, the dae-c2− moiety has a closed-ring structure by making a single bond, C(19)**−C(20).

Crystal Structure of 1c

 1c crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/m with an inversion center on the [Mn4] moiety and a mirror plane through the dae-c2- ligand (Z = 2; Table ). Similar to 1o, 1c has an infinite 1-D chain structure composed of [Mn4] double-cuboidal units and the dae-c2- ligands in an alternating arrangement [-{Mn4}-(dae-c)-] (Figure a), in which the dae-c2- ligand acts as a bidentate ligand coordinating to the outer Mn sites of the [Mn4] unit via carboxylate groups. The (R,R) and (S,S) enantiomers of dae-c2- were disordered because they sit in the same site with an occupancy ratio of 1:1, and the hexafluorocyclopentene ring of dae-c2- was also disordered similar to that of 1o (). An ORTEP drawing of the repeating unit in the 1-D chain of 1c is shown in Figure b, and selected bond distances and angles in the [Mn4] core are listed in . The [Mn4] moiety has a [Mn4(hmp)6]4+ core. The outer and inner Mn ions were assigned to be MnII and MnIII on the basis of bond valence sum (BVS) calculations and structural characteristics (vide infra). As in the case of 1o, the inner MnIII ions are hexacoordinated, and the outer MnII ions are heptacoordinated. However, the terminal ligand on the MnII ion is a water molecule instead of ClO4 - which is the terminal ligand in 1o. The ClO4 - ions are located between chains. The two MnIII ions exhibited Jahn-Teller elongation of the O(3)*-Mn(2)-N(2)* and O(3)-Mn(2)*-N(2) axes with Mn(2)-N(2)* = 2.220(5) Å, Mn(2)-O(3)* = 2.280(3) Å, and O(3)*-Mn(2)-N(2)* = 161.19(18)°. The two Jahn-Teller axes were parallel to each other in the core. As we can see in Figure b, the dae-c2- moiety has a closed-ring structure by making a single bond, C(19)**-C(20).

elements.content: Figure shows packing diagrams of 1c. The 1-D chains are parallel to the b axis of the crystal lattice. The [Mn4] units and the dae-c2− ligands were alternately stacked to form a 2-D layered structure (Figure a). The Jahn−Teller axes of the [Mn4] cores are alternately arranged in the chains with a tilt angle of about 70° because of the presence of the mirror symmetry on the dae-c2− ligand. The intrachain interunit MnII···MnII distance across the dae-c2− ligand was 13.186 Å. Different from the structure of 1o, the interchain interunit distance (5.703 Å for MnII···MnII) in 1c was significantly small (Figure b). This close contact may give rise to magnetic interactions between the [Mn4] cores in the neighboring chains (vide infra).

elements.content: Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on microcrystalline samples of 1o and 1c restrained in Nujol in a 1 kOe dc field in the temperature range 1.82−300 K. The temperature dependence of χT products is shown in Figure . Basically, 1o and 1c showed similar behavior to the previously reported [Mn4] SMMs. The χT value at 300 K was ∼16 cm3 K mol−1 for both compounds, which is consistent with the spin-only value expected for a set of noninteracting isotropic magnetic centers of S Mn(II) = 5/2 × 2 and S Mn(III) = 2 × 2 with g = 2 (14.75 cm3 K mol−1), and upon lowering the temperature, it increased to a maximum of 40.65 cm3 K mol−1 at 4.3 K and 36.82 cm3 K mol−1 at 7.5 K for 1o and 1c, respectively. This increase is due to ferromagnetic interactions among the Mn ions in the [Mn4] core. Please note that the exchange couplings between the MnIII ions and between the MnII and MnIII ions are denoted hereafter as J bb and J wb, respectively. The experimental data were simulated to estimate J bb and J wb using the Heisenberg−Van Vleck model, which has already been used with analogous [Mn4] clusters [ H = −2J bb( S Mn(III) S Mn(III)′) − 2J wb( S Mn(II) + S Mn(II)′)( S Mn(III) + S Mn(III)′)]. The data below 7 K for 1o and 13 K for 1c, of which χT decreased, were omitted to avoid the effects of zero-field splitting (ZFS) and/or intercluster interactions. In fact, these effects were not taken into account in this simulation to avoid the overparameterization. With temperature-independent paramagnetism (TIP) fixed to 6 × 10−4 cm3 mol−1, excellent fits were obtained for both an adequate parameter set and positive values of J bb and J wb where J bb > J wb (Table ). The ranges of J bb and J wb are almost similar to those for related [Mn4] with S T = 9.
elements.clean_text:
DC Magnetic Measurements on 1o and 1c

Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on microcrystalline samples of 1o and 1c restrained in Nujol in a 1 kOe dc field in the temperature range 1.82-300 K. The temperature dependence of χT products is shown in Figure . Basically, 1o and 1c showed similar behavior to the previously reported [Mn4] SMMs. The χT value at 300 K was ~16 cm3 K mol-1 for both compounds, which is consistent with the spin-only value expected for a set of noninteracting isotropic magnetic centers of S Mn(II) = 5/2 × 2 and S Mn(III) = 2 × 2 with g = 2 (14.75 cm3 K mol-1), and upon lowering the temperature, it increased to a maximum of 40.65 cm3 K mol-1 at 4.3 K and 36.82 cm3 K mol-1 at 7.5 K for 1o and 1c, respectively. This increase is due to ferromagnetic interactions among the Mn ions in the [Mn4] core. Please note that the exchange couplings between the MnIII ions and between the MnII and MnIII ions are denoted hereafter as J bb and J wb, respectively. The experimental data were simulated to estimate J bb and J wb using the Heisenberg-Van Vleck model, which has already been used with analogous [Mn4] clusters [ H  = -2J bb( S  Mn(III)  S  Mn(III)') - 2J wb( S  Mn(II) +  S  Mn(II)')( S  Mn(III) +  S  Mn(III)')]. The data below 7 K for 1o and 13 K for 1c, of which χT decreased, were omitted to avoid the effects of zero-field splitting (ZFS) and/or intercluster interactions. In fact, these effects were not taken into account in this simulation to avoid the overparameterization. With temperature-independent paramagnetism (TIP) fixed to 6 × 10-4 cm3 mol-1, excellent fits were obtained for both an adequate parameter set and positive values of J bb and J wb where J bb > J wb (Table ). The ranges of J bb and J wb are almost similar to those for related [Mn4] with S T = 9.

To confirm the anisotropic nature of the spin ground state (S T), the reduced magnetization at high fields (1−7 T) and low temperatures (1.8−4.5 K) of 1o and 1c was examined. Figure shows plots of M/Nμ B vs H/T, where M is the magnetization, N is Avogadro’s number, μB is the Bohr magneton, and H is the applied magnetic field. At H = 7 T and T = 1.8 K, 1o and 1c showed saturated magnetization values of 16−17 μB. The nonsuperposition of the isofield curves is indicative of the presence of axial zero-field splitting, i.e., the axial zero-field splitting parameter (D) < 0. A best-fit simulation performed by using a matrix-diagonalization method taking into account only S T = 9 and its axial zero-field splitting term (DS Tz 2) afforded g av = 1.96, D/k B = −0.31 K for 1o and g av = 1.88, D/k B = −0.33 K for 1c. The obtained D value is similar to that of the previously reported [Mn4] SMMs. In other words, both compounds have the potential to be SMMs. For SMMs with integer spins, the theoretical energy barrier for the magnetization relaxation, Δ, is expressed as Δ = |D|S T 2. From the obtained D value and S T = 9, the theoretical values Δ/k B were estimated to be 25.1 and 26.7 K for 1o and 1c, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Estimation of the Axial Zero-Field Splitting Parameter D on the Basis of S T 

To confirm the anisotropic nature of the spin ground state (S T), the reduced magnetization at high fields (1-7 T) and low temperatures (1.8-4.5 K) of 1o and 1c was examined. Figure  shows plots of M/Nμ B vs H/T, where M is the magnetization, N is Avogadro's number, μB is the Bohr magneton, and H is the applied magnetic field. At H = 7 T and T = 1.8 K, 1o and 1c showed saturated magnetization values of 16-17 μB. The nonsuperposition of the isofield curves is indicative of the presence of axial zero-field splitting, i.e., the axial zero-field splitting parameter (D) < 0. A best-fit simulation performed by using a matrix-diagonalization method taking into account only S T = 9 and its axial zero-field splitting term (DS Tz 2) afforded g av = 1.96, D/k B = -0.31 K for 1o and g av = 1.88, D/k B = -0.33 K for 1c. The obtained D value is similar to that of the previously reported [Mn4] SMMs. In other words, both compounds have the potential to be SMMs. For SMMs with integer spins, the theoretical energy barrier for the magnetization relaxation, Δ, is expressed as Δ = |D|S T 2. From the obtained D value and S T = 9, the theoretical values Δ/k B were estimated to be 25.1 and 26.7 K for 1o and 1c, respectively.

elements.content: We are aware that the behavior of the magnetization even for 1c (Figure ) is close to that observed for isolated SMMs with negligible inter-SMM interaction or very weak interactions that only behave as a perturbation. Even at 1 T, the magnetization monotonically increased with a decrease in the temperature and hence followed the simulated curve. This indicates that the magnetic superexchange between [Mn4] units with S T = 9 through the dae bridge is very small, even in the closed-ring form (see the next section).

Even at 1 T, the magnetization monotonically increased with a decrease in the temperature and hence followed the simulated curve. This indicates that the magnetic superexchange between [Mn4] units with S T = 9 through the dae bridge is very small, even in the closed-ring form (see the next section).

elements.content: Ac magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on microcrystalline samples with a 3 Oe oscillation field and a zero dc field as a function of the temperature and frequency (ν) to determine the SMM behavior of 1o and 1c. Figure shows the temperature dependence of the ac susceptibilities (χ′ is the real (in-phase) part and χ′′ is the imaginary (out-of-phase) part) measured at several ac frequencies for 1o and 1c. As expected for SMMs, both χ′ and χ′′ were frequency-dependent, although a peak top of χ′′, which indicates the freezing of the magnetization at a frequency, was not observed even at 1.8 K with 1500 Hz, suggesting slow relaxation of the magnetization of 1o and 1c. To estimate the relaxation time (τ) from the nonmaximum χ′′ data, the χ′′ vs ν data measured at fixed temperatures were simulated by using the Debye model for a distributed single-relaxation process of the magnetization (Figure ). From the simulated curve, τ can be determined at a specific temperature using the relation τ = 1/2πν max. The obtained relaxation times at several temperatures obeyed the Arrhenius law τ(T) = τ0 exp(Δeff/k B T) (Figure ) with Δeff/k B = 9.2 K, τ0 = 3.2 × 10−7 s and Δeff/k B = 12.1 K, τ0 = 1.7 × 10−7 s for 1o and 1c, respectively. Despite the rough estimation, the obtained τ0 and Δeff values are comparable with those for previously reported [Mn4] SMMs. Δeff was smaller than the theoretical value (Δ) estimated from Δ = |D|S T 2 using the D values obtained from the reduced magnetization measurements (vide supra). This is reasonable because the reversal of the magnetization of an SMM possibly involves not only the thermal activation over Δ but also the quantum tunneling of the magnetization (QTM), which is a “short-cut” through Δ. Thus, the smaller Δeff due to QTM in the ground state is typical even in the family of [Mn4] SMMs. QTM should be suppressed by applying a dc field because of a mismatch between +m s and −m s magnetization levels by Zeeman splitting, which is evidence for SMM behavior. Ac measurements in the presence of an applied dc field afforded a larger Δeff value closer to Δ (): Δeff/k B = 12.8 K with τ0 = 9.9 × 10−8 s for 1o at 1 kOe and Δeff/k B = 20.5 K with τ0 = 5.5 × 10−9 s for 1c at 2 kOe. The above ac magnetic data suggest that the each [Mn4] unit in 1o and 1c behaves as an SMM.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Molecule Magnet Behavior in 1o and 1c

Ac magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on microcrystalline samples with a 3 Oe oscillation field and a zero dc field as a function of the temperature and frequency (ν) to determine the SMM behavior of 1o and 1c. Figure  shows the temperature dependence of the ac susceptibilities (χ' is the real (in-phase) part and χ'' is the imaginary (out-of-phase) part) measured at several ac frequencies for 1o and 1c. As expected for SMMs, both χ' and χ'' were frequency-dependent, although a peak top of χ'', which indicates the freezing of the magnetization at a frequency, was not observed even at 1.8 K with 1500 Hz, suggesting slow relaxation of the magnetization of 1o and 1c. To estimate the relaxation time (τ) from the nonmaximum χ'' data, the χ'' vs ν data measured at fixed temperatures were simulated by using the Debye model for a distributed single-relaxation process of the magnetization (Figure ). From the simulated curve, τ can be determined at a specific temperature using the relation τ = 1/2πν max. The obtained relaxation times at several temperatures obeyed the Arrhenius law τ(T) = τ0 exp(Δeff/k B T) (Figure ) with Δeff/k B = 9.2 K, τ0 = 3.2 × 10-7 s and Δeff/k B = 12.1 K, τ0 = 1.7 × 10-7 s for 1o and 1c, respectively. Despite the rough estimation, the obtained τ0 and Δeff values are comparable with those for previously reported [Mn4] SMMs. Δeff was smaller than the theoretical value (Δ) estimated from Δ = |D|S T 2 using the D values obtained from the reduced magnetization measurements (vide supra). This is reasonable because the reversal of the magnetization of an SMM possibly involves not only the thermal activation over Δ but also the quantum tunneling of the magnetization (QTM), which is a "short-cut" through Δ. Thus, the smaller Δeff due to QTM in the ground state is typical even in the family of [Mn4] SMMs. QTM should be suppressed by applying a dc field because of a mismatch between +m s and -m s magnetization levels by Zeeman splitting, which is evidence for SMM behavior. Ac measurements in the presence of an applied dc field afforded a larger Δeff value closer to Δ (): Δeff/k B = 12.8 K with τ0 = 9.9 × 10-8 s for 1o at 1 kOe and Δeff/k B = 20.5 K with τ0 = 5.5 × 10-9 s for 1c at 2 kOe. The above ac magnetic data suggest that the each [Mn4] unit in 1o and 1c behaves as an SMM.

elements.content: The SMM behavior in 1o and 1c was also examined by measuring the field dependence of the magnetization (M vs H) at low temperatures. It should be mentioned that, as supposed from the ac data, no field hysteresis of the magnetization was observed at 1.8 K for both compounds (). Further investigation was performed at 0.5 K on a field-oriented single crystal that was restrained in n-eicosane with an applied field of 70 kOe at 325 K, followed by cooling in the field (Figure ). In the measurement, data were collected by applying fields at a scanning rate of 2 Oe s−1 parallel to the averaged easy axis direction of the [Mn4] units in the crystals (see Experimental Section). 1o showed a weak hysteretic response (butterfly−type hysteresis feature) with no coercive field (Figure a). On the other hand, 1c showed a more distinct hysteresis loop with a small coercive field (≈ 100 Oe) and several steps (Figure b). Some of these steps, for example at −1.3 and 1.1 kOe, can be indicative of QTM, although the imperfect alignment of the crystal can cause a false step, such as that at H = 0. The step at ca. 3.5 kOe may be due to thermal activation. The steps at −1.3 and 1.1 kOe could be due to QTM between m s = 9 and m s = −9 and −8, respectively. From the field interval between the steps (ΔH = 2.4 kOe), a |D|/k B value of 0.32 K (ΔH ≈ |D|/gμ B) was determined, which agrees with the value obtained from the reduced magnetization. It is noteworthy that the first step (−1.3 kOe) corresponding to QTM between m s = ± 9 was observed before the external field was decreased to zero. This shift in the field at which the QTM occurred suggests the presence of very weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the [Mn4] units in 1c (|zJ|/k B ≈ 1 × 10−2 K from |zJ| = gμ B H ex/2S T with H ex = 1.3 kOe = 0.13 T). Albeit very small, these interactions could be the result of close inter-[Mn4] contact between the neighboring 1-D chains (5.703 Å) and/or the inter-[Mn4] connection through the dae-c2− ligand in a chain.

elements.content: It is well-known that the diarylethene group (dae) undergoes a reversible isomerization between open- and closed-ring isomers upon irradiation with UV (o → c) and visible light (c → o) even in the solid state, which causes a drastic color change characteristic of the chromophore of respective isomers. The photochromic reactivity of 1o and 1c in the solid state was thus examined through visual color changes using KBr-diluted pellet samples of both compounds and changes in absorption spectra. Figure a shows photographs and absorption spectra of 1o. Before photoirradiation, the 1o-KBr pellet was reddish-brown due to the [Mn4] chromophore (dae-o is colorless). Upon irradiation with UV light (λ = 313 nm), the 1o-KBr pellet turned dark blue. This color change indicated that the dae-o moiety in 1o underwent photocyclization to the corresponding closed-ring isomer (dae-c) in the crystal. Furthermore, irradiation of the blue pellet with visible light (λ > 480 nm) caused the initial reddish-brown one to return, indicating that the photogenerated closed-ring isomer also underwent cycloreversion to the open-ring isomer. In other words, the color change is photoreversible, and isomerization between the dae-o and dae-c isomers occurs reversibly in the solid state of 1o. This reversible photochromic reaction was also examined by using absorption spectroscopy. Figure a also shows the photoinduced absorption-spectral changes of a powder sample of 1o dispersed in a BaSO4 matrix. Before photoirradiation, characteristic absorption bands around 580 and 980 nm corresponding to electronic transitions in the [Mn4] chromophore were observed. Upon irradiation with UV light, a new absorption band appeared around 600 nm because of the formation of the dae-c isomer. This absorption band has been observed for the closed-ring isomer photogenerated in a single crystal of H2dae-o. As expected from the visual color change, the newly generated absorption band obtained by UV irradiation disappeared upon irradiation with visible light.
elements.clean_text:
Photochromic Reactions in 1o and 1c

It is well-known that the diarylethene group (dae) undergoes a reversible isomerization between open- and closed-ring isomers upon irradiation with UV (o → c) and visible light (c → o) even in the solid state, which causes a drastic color change characteristic of the chromophore of respective isomers. The photochromic reactivity of 1o and 1c in the solid state was thus examined through visual color changes using KBr-diluted pellet samples of both compounds and changes in absorption spectra. Figure a shows photographs and absorption spectra of 1o. Before photoirradiation, the 1o-KBr pellet was reddish-brown due to the [Mn4] chromophore (dae-o is colorless). Upon irradiation with UV light (λ = 313 nm), the 1o-KBr pellet turned dark blue. This color change indicated that the dae-o moiety in 1o underwent photocyclization to the corresponding closed-ring isomer (dae-c) in the crystal. Furthermore, irradiation of the blue pellet with visible light (λ > 480 nm) caused the initial reddish-brown one to return, indicating that the photogenerated closed-ring isomer also underwent cycloreversion to the open-ring isomer. In other words, the color change is photoreversible, and isomerization between the dae-o and dae-c isomers occurs reversibly in the solid state of 1o. This reversible photochromic reaction was also examined by using absorption spectroscopy. Figure a also shows the photoinduced absorption-spectral changes of a powder sample of 1o dispersed in a BaSO4 matrix. Before photoirradiation, characteristic absorption bands around 580 and 980 nm corresponding to electronic transitions in the [Mn4] chromophore were observed. Upon irradiation with UV light, a new absorption band appeared around 600 nm because of the formation of the dae-c isomer. This absorption band has been observed for the closed-ring isomer photogenerated in a single crystal of H2dae-o. As expected from the visual color change, the newly generated absorption band obtained by UV irradiation disappeared upon irradiation with visible light.

elements.content: The photochromism of 1c was also examined (Figure b). Before photoirradiation, the 1c-KBr pellet was dark blue (consistent with the color of UV-irradiated 1o). Upon irradiation with visible light, the pellet turned reddish-brown due to the photocycloreversion of the dae-c moiety to form dae-o. Then, upon irradiation with UV light, the pellet turned dark blue again, indicating that dae-c was regenerated by the photocyclization of the dae-o moiety. The changes in the absorption spectra shown in Figure b also corresponded to these photochromic reactions. The conversion ratio of the open- to closed-ring isomers in the photostationary state under photoirradiation at 313 nm was estimated to be 75% by comparing the absorbances at 600 nm for the closed-ring isomer before and after irradiation.

elements.content: The effects of the photoinduced isomerization of dae on the magnetic properties was the main subject of this work. The dc and ac magnetic measurements were performed on a microcrystalline powder sample of 1o irradiated at 313 nm for 26 h (denoted hereafter as 1o-UV). The conversion ratio from the open- to closed-ring forms in 1o-UV was estimated to be ∼30% by measuring an absorption spectrum of the irradiated sample in a methanolic solution, and further irradiation did not increase the conversion. The relatively low conversion ratio is due to the inhomogeneity of the photoreaction, which mainly occurs near the surface of the crystalline powder, and/or the suppression of the conversion due to the simultaneous cycloreversion reaction. There was no significant change in X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns measured in the low 2θ angle range (5°−25°) between before and after the UV irradiation (a). The magnetic data for 1o-UV are shown in . The data were the same as those for the unirradiated sample of 1o, and no meaningful change in the magnetic properties was induced by photoirradiation.
elements.clean_text:
Effect of Photochromic Reactions on the Magnetic Properties

The effects of the photoinduced isomerization of dae on the magnetic properties was the main subject of this work. The dc and ac magnetic measurements were performed on a microcrystalline powder sample of 1o irradiated at 313 nm for 26 h (denoted hereafter as 1o-UV). The conversion ratio from the open- to closed-ring forms in 1o-UV was estimated to be ~30% by measuring an absorption spectrum of the irradiated sample in a methanolic solution, and further irradiation did not increase the conversion. The relatively low conversion ratio is due to the inhomogeneity of the photoreaction, which mainly occurs near the surface of the crystalline powder, and/or the suppression of the conversion due to the simultaneous cycloreversion reaction. There was no significant change in X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns measured in the low 2θ angle range (5°-25°) between before and after the UV irradiation (a). The magnetic data for 1o-UV are shown in . The data were the same as those for the unirradiated sample of 1o, and no meaningful change in the magnetic properties was induced by photoirradiation.

elements.content: In contrast, a drastic change in the magnetic properties of 1c was observed after irradiation with visible light for 3 h. A microcrystalline powder sample of 1c was irradiated until the conversion ratio was 100% determined from an absorption spectrum of a methanolic solution (hereafter denoted as 1c-vis). XRPD data for 1c-vis indicate that the crystallinity of the irradiated sample was preserved even after the 100% conversion (b). The characteristic change between those of 1c and 1c-vis can be found as the somewhat shift of some diffraction peaks of 1c-vis to lower angles, which suggests that the crystal structure underwent some modifications and the lattice was expanded by the geometrical change of the dae moiety accompanying its cycloreversion reaction. Simulations of their diffraction patterns allowed a rough estimatation of the cell parameters for 1c and 1c-vis and estimated a degree of change of cell parameters as Δa = 1.83%, Δb = −0.13%, Δc = 3.69%, Δβ = −0.13%, and ΔV = 5.53% using Δlattice(%) = (1c-vis − 1c)/1c × 100. The ac plane, which includes the shortest [Mn4]···[Mn4] distance (5.703 Å along the a axis in 1c), was in particular expanded despite no significant change in the b axis corresponding to the chain direction. Therefore, we suppose that this change is a key factor for the following magnetic change. Figure shows the χT vs T data for 1c-vis together with those of 1c. Upon lowering the temperature, the χT value for 1c-vis increased from 15.7 cm3 K mol−1 at 300 K to 22.7 cm3 K mol−1 at 27 K and then dropped sharply to 6.9 cm3 K mol−1 at 1.8 K. The data for 1c could be superimposed on those for 1c-vis in the range 150−300 K. However, the data for 1c-vis below 150 K were much smaller than those for 1c, indicating that the photoinduced isomerization from dae-c to dae-o caused a change in the magnetic properties.

elements.content: A large change induced by irradiation with visible light was also observed in the M vs H data. Figure a shows M vs H data at 1.8 K measured on random polycrystalline samples of 1c and 1c-vis restrained in Nujol. The magnetization of 1c-vis showed a relatively rapid increase at low field strengths (2.5 μB at 5 kOe) and then increased quasi-linearly to 11.8 μB at ∼40 kOe with a broad inflection at ∼25.6 kOe, followed by a gradual increase to 16.0 μB at 70 kOe. The values at individual field strengths were considerably lower than those for 1c. The M vs H data of 1c-vis were also measured at 0.5 K using a field-oriented single-crystal sample (Figure b). A weak hysteresis response (butterfly−type) with no coercivity was observed for 1c-vis. It should be noted that a similar inflection is also found in this measurement at almost the same field of H c ≈ 26 kOe (). The inflection in the M vs H curve suggests the presence of intermolecular interactions among [Mn4] units, in which antiferromagnetically coupled S T spins of [Mn4] units experience a flip when the magnitude of the interactions is overcome by an applied field H c as seen in metamagnetic systems. Similar behavior has been observed in antiferromagnetically ordered systems of a double-cuboidal [Mn4] SMM and a square-shaped [Mn4] SMM. This instability can be expressed as the Ising limit at 0 K: H c(0 K) = 2|zJ′|S T/gμ B, where z is the number of neighboring spins, J′ is the antiferromagnetic coupling constant, and S T = 9 for 1c-vis. Assuming H c(0) = 25.6 kOe = 2.56 T, the magnetic interaction between the [Mn4] units is estimated to be |zJ′|/k B ≈ 0.19 K. The dc data prove that the photoirradiation of visible light to 1c indirectly enhances [Mn4] interunit interactions. It is important to note that, considering the structural change upon isomerization from dae-c to dae-o induced by irradiation, the present [Mn4] interunit interaction should be a through-space interaction (possibly in the ac directions) rather than a through-bond one via the dae-o linkage.

elements.content: To gain further understanding of the magnetic properties of 1c-vis, ac susceptibility measurements were performed (Figure ). Similar to the χT vs T data in Figure , the values of χ′ of 1c-vis at low temperatures were smaller than the corresponding ones of 1c; however, they were strongly frequency-dependent showing an increase in χ′′ (Figure a). Furthermore, the maxima of χ′′, which were not observed for 1c, were observed above 1.8 K at ac frequencies in the range 200−1500 Hz. However, they were not single component values, indicating the existence of multiple relaxation processes. To determine the origins of the relaxation processes, ac susceptibilities were measured as a function of the ac frequency (1−1500 Hz) at several temperatures (Figure b). The χ′′ vs ν data clearly showed the presence of two modes of relaxation: high-frequency and low-frequency modes. This has been observed for antiferromagnetically coupled [Mn4] SMMs. Only in the low-frequency mode were peak tops observed in the frequency and temperature ranges measured (indicated as arrows in Figure b), and from an Arrhenius plot, τ0 = 2.68 × 10−14 s and Δeff/k B = 46.7 K. The value of τ0 is much faster compared to general values observed for SMMs (τ0 = 10−7−10−10 s) and is similar to those of spin-glass-like materials that have short- and long-range multidomains. In addition, the Δeff/k B value is significantly larger than Δ/k Β = |D|S T 2/k Β ≈ 26 K expected for 1o and 1c. Consequently, we attributed the slow relaxation to the effect of the [Mn4] interunit antiferromagnetic short- and/or long-range ordering. The data in the high-frequency mode up to 1500 Hz at 1.8 K showing no peak tops were attributed to the relaxation of the magnetization of the [Mn4] SMM unit. This hypothesis is supported by similar observations for other antiferromagnetically coupled [Mn4] SMMs, where multiple relaxation processes are related to the applied ac frequencies. On the basis of dc and ac magnetic data, we concluded that the photocycloreversion of the dae-c moiety in 1c caused the formation of a new magnetic phase, which combines the characteristics of [Mn4] SMM unit and antiferromagnetic ordering.

elements.content: Finally, to check the reversibility of this photoinduced change, the magnetic properties of 1c-vis irradiated with UV light for 3.5 h (hereafter referred to as 1c-vis−UV) were measured. The conversion ratio from the open to the closed form was 75%. After UV irradiation, the data nearly returned to those of 1c; they were not identical because of the incomplete conversion of dae-o to dae-c and possible structural fluctuations (). Nevertheless, in the case of the ac susceptibility data, the [Mn4] interunit interactions observed in the low-frequency mode disappeared, and only the data for the high-frequency mode as well as those for 1c remained (Figure ). This reversibility indicates that the photoinduced change in the magnetic properties comes from the photoisomerization of the photochromic dae moiety.

elements.content: Here, we discuss the origin of the antiferromagnetic interactions in the visible-irradiated 1c-vis and the difference in the photoresponsive behavior of 1o and 1c. As mentioned above, open-ring form 1o exhibited no change in the magnetic properties after photocyclization with UV irradiation. On the other hand, closed-ring form 1c underwent a significant photoinduced change in the dc and ac magnetic data: After the photocycloreversion with visible irradiation, we obtained credible magnetic data for 1c-vis showing the presence of antiferromagnetic ordering of the S T spins of the [Mn4] units.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion of the Photoinduced Change in the Magnetic Properties

Here, we discuss the origin of the antiferromagnetic interactions in the visible-irradiated 1c-vis and the difference in the photoresponsive behavior of 1o and 1c. As mentioned above, open-ring form 1o exhibited no change in the magnetic properties after photocyclization with UV irradiation. On the other hand, closed-ring form 1c underwent a significant photoinduced change in the dc and ac magnetic data: After the photocycloreversion with visible irradiation, we obtained credible magnetic data for 1c-vis showing the presence of antiferromagnetic ordering of the S T spins of the [Mn4] units.

elements.content: As mentioned in the introduction, we propose two plausible mechanisms to explain the photoswitching of the [Mn4] interunit interactions: (I) direct switching of superexchange interactions through the π-system of the dae moiety (intrachain switching; Scheme a) and (II) indirect switching of the [Mn4] interchain interactions due to the change in the distance between [Mn4] units of neighboring 1-D chains (interchain switching; Scheme b). Mechanism I should occur preferentially with the closed-ring dae because the π-conjugation is spread over the entire molecule (Scheme a). However, the intermolecular magnetic interactions are greater in 1c-vis having a dae-o moiety. Thus, mechanism I does not explain the occurrence of the antiferromagnetic interactions in 1c-vis, whereas mechanism II does. The structural change in the dae moiety of 1c from dae-c to dae-o upon photocycloreversion should cause a change in the packing geometry of [Mn4] units or the arrangement of the 1-D chains (Scheme ). The comparison of XRPD patterns between 1c and 1c-vis suggests that the structural change, in particular in the ac plane associated with interchain through-space interactions, was induced by the photoreaction (). The short distance between relatively large spins with S T = 9, as the a direction seen in 1c, is more sensitive to changes in the structure, which strongly influences the [Mn4] interunit interactions. Actually even in 1c, there is a very weak antiferromagnetic interaction between the [Mn4] units (zJ/k B ≈ −1 × 10−2 K). Since the dae derivatives change their geometrical structures, especially the position of their thiophene rings, during photocyclization and photocycloreversion in the single crystals, the crystal packing is greatly affected, sometimes leading to a large strain in the single crystal itself. The change may be small; however, it should be enough to trigger a significant enhancement of the antiferromagnetic interactions (zJ/k B ≈ −0.19 K) because the distance between the [Mn4] units in the initial 1c is already fairly close.

elements.content: The difference in the photoresponsive behavior of 1o and 1c is due to the difference in their packing structures. The closest Mn···Mn distance between the neighboring chains in 1o is 8.453 Å, whereas, in 1c, it is 5.703 Å. In other words, the structural change induced by photocyclization of the dae moiety in 1o scarcely affected the [Mn4] arrangement. In addition, the low conversion ratio from the UV-induced cyclization also hinders any drastic change in the magnetic properties.
elements.clean_text: The difference in the photoresponsive behavior of 1o and 1c is due to the difference in their packing structures. The closest Mn⋅⋅⋅Mn distance between the neighboring chains in 1o is 8.453 Å, whereas, in 1c, it is 5.703 Å. In other words, the structural change induced by photocyclization of the dae moiety in 1o scarcely affected the [Mn4] arrangement. In addition, the low conversion ratio from the UV-induced cyclization also hinders any drastic change in the magnetic properties.

elements.content: In this paper, to the best of our knowledge, we prepared the first example of a coordination assembly of an SMM and a photochromic bridging ligand using a double-cuboidal [Mn4] SMM and a diarylethene derivative with two carboxylate groups (dae). Using the open- and closed-ring forms of dae, dae-o2− and dae-c2−, afforded 1-D chain assemblies (1o and 1c, respectively) with dae coordinating to the [Mn4] via the carboxylate groups and with the SMM units and dae ligands in an alternating arrangement, [−{Mn4}−(dae)−]. Dc and ac magnetic measurements on 1o and 1c showed that they behaved as SMMs with S T = 9, similar to previously reported double-cuboidal [Mn4] SMMs, despite being bridged by the dae groups. The open-ring form (dae-o) underwent photocyclization upon irradiation with UV to produce the closed-ring form (dae-c), and dae-c underwent photocycloreversion to dae-o upon irradiation with visible light. No significant change in the magnetic properties of 1o-UV was observed when 1o was photocyclized, although dae-c in 1o-UV should have a well-conjugated π-pathway. In contrast, photocycloreversion for 1c by visible irradiation (dae-c → dae-o) led to a drastic change in the magnetic behavior of 1c-vis, and [Mn4] interunit interactions were detected. The interactions were assigned to be through-space interactions rather than through-bond ones via the dae-o linkage, and they were caused by a change in the [Mn4] arrangement between the neighboring 1-D chains due to the geometrical change in the dae moiety during the photoreaction. We concluded that the difference in the photoresponsive behaviors of 1o and 1c was due to the difference in the packing structures of the 1-D chains in the crystals.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this paper, to the best of our knowledge, we prepared the first example of a coordination assembly of an SMM and a photochromic bridging ligand using a double-cuboidal [Mn4] SMM and a diarylethene derivative with two carboxylate groups (dae). Using the open- and closed-ring forms of dae, dae-o2- and dae-c2-, afforded 1-D chain assemblies (1o and 1c, respectively) with dae coordinating to the [Mn4] via the carboxylate groups and with the SMM units and dae ligands in an alternating arrangement, [-{Mn4}-(dae)-]. Dc and ac magnetic measurements on 1o and 1c showed that they behaved as SMMs with S T = 9, similar to previously reported double-cuboidal [Mn4] SMMs, despite being bridged by the dae groups. The open-ring form (dae-o) underwent photocyclization upon irradiation with UV to produce the closed-ring form (dae-c), and dae-c underwent photocycloreversion to dae-o upon irradiation with visible light. No significant change in the magnetic properties of 1o-UV was observed when 1o was photocyclized, although dae-c in 1o-UV should have a well-conjugated π-pathway. In contrast, photocycloreversion for 1c by visible irradiation (dae-c → dae-o) led to a drastic change in the magnetic behavior of 1c-vis, and [Mn4] interunit interactions were detected. The interactions were assigned to be through-space interactions rather than through-bond ones via the dae-o linkage, and they were caused by a change in the [Mn4] arrangement between the neighboring 1-D chains due to the geometrical change in the dae moiety during the photoreaction. We concluded that the difference in the photoresponsive behaviors of 1o and 1c was due to the difference in the packing structures of the 1-D chains in the crystals.

elements.content: The results obtained in this work illustrate the usefulness of the photochromic molecules for photoswitching of the magnetic behavior, even superparamagnetic behavior, in SMMs and will open the door to the development of an uncharted series of multifunctional and stimulus-responsive SMMs. Photoswitching strongly depends on the packing structures of the crystals, and desirable functions are likely achieved by photoswitching of the through-bond magnetic pathways of a photochromic bridging ligand, as described in Scheme a. This work will enable the photoswitching of the spin dynamics (memory ON and OFF) of isolated photochromic SMM assemblies.

This work will enable the photoswitching of the spin dynamics (memory ON and OFF) of isolated photochromic SMM assemblies.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures and Materials

All chemicals and solvents were used as received. The diarylethene ligands H2dae-o and H2dae-c were synthesized according to the same method as described in the literature. All preparations and manipulations were carried out under aerobic conditions.

elements.content: To an acetonitrile solution (20 mL) of manganese perchlorate hexahydrate (724 mg, 2.0 mmol) were added an acetonitrile solution (10 mL) of 2-hydroxymethylpyridine (546 mg, 5.0 mmol) and a 20 wt % aqueous solution of tetraethylammonium hydroxide (1.47 g, 2.0 mmol). After the mixture stirred for 15 min at room temperature, an acetonitrile solution (10 mL) of H2dae-o (228 mg, 0.5 mmol) was added, and then the reaction solution was stirred for 1 h. The resulting solution was filtered and carefully layered on chloroform (80 mL) in a narrow diameter glass tube. After several days, black crystals of 1o were obtained. Yield: 110 mg, 13% (based on Mn). Selected IR (KBr): 3429 (m), 2848 (m), 1606 (s), 1558 (s), 1481 (s), 1439 (s), 1404 (s), 1385 (s), 1371 (s), 1275 (s), 1186 (m), 1119 (s), 1045 (s), 984 (m), 810 (m) cm−1. Anal. Calcd for C53H56Cl2F6Mn4N6O24S2: C, 39.06; H, 3.46; N, 5.16. Found: C, 39.19; H, 3.18; N, 5.16.

elements.content: Infrared spectra were measured as KBr pellets on a JASCO FT/IR-620 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer. Solid-state absorption spectra were measured in BaSO4 matrices with a Shimadzu UV-3150 spectrophotometer. Photoirradiation was carried out with an Asahi Spectra MAX-301 300 W xenon lamp system. The wavelength was selected by passing the light through a band-pass filter or a cutoff filter. Magnetic measurements were obtained with the use of a Quantum Design MPMS-XL superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer. Dc measurements were collected in the temperature range 1.8−300 K and field amplitude range −70−70 kOe. Ac measurements were collected at various frequencies from 1 to 1488 Hz with an ac field amplitude of 3 Oe. Freshly prepared crystalline samples of 1o and 1c were used for the magnetic measurements to avoid deterioration of the samples, and the measurements were performed using finely ground microcrystalline powder samples restrained in Nujol. Magnetization measurements at 0.5 K were obtained in an i-Quantum 3He refrigeration system (i-Helium3) attached to the MPMS-XL magnetometer. The measurements were performed on single-crystalline samples restrained in n-eicosane after prefield orientation by applying a field with an amplitude of 70 kOe at 325 K. The experimental data were corrected for the sample holder, the resin, and the diamagnetic contribution calculated from Pascal constants.

Physical Measurements

Infrared spectra were measured as KBr pellets on a JASCO FT/IR-620 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer. Solid-state absorption spectra were measured in BaSO4 matrices with a Shimadzu UV-3150 spectrophotometer. Photoirradiation was carried out with an Asahi Spectra MAX-301 300 W xenon lamp system. The wavelength was selected by passing the light through a band-pass filter or a cutoff filter. Magnetic measurements were obtained with the use of a Quantum Design MPMS-XL superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer. Dc measurements were collected in the temperature range 1.8-300 K and field amplitude range -70-70 kOe. Ac measurements were collected at various frequencies from 1 to 1488 Hz with an ac field amplitude of 3 Oe. Freshly prepared crystalline samples of 1o and 1c were used for the magnetic measurements to avoid deterioration of the samples, and the measurements were performed using finely ground microcrystalline powder samples restrained in Nujol. Magnetization measurements at 0.5 K were obtained in an i-Quantum 3He refrigeration system (i-Helium3) attached to the MPMS-XL magnetometer. The measurements were performed on single-crystalline samples restrained in n-eicosane after prefield orientation by applying a field with an amplitude of 70 kOe at 325 K. elements.content: Single crystals of 1o and 1c for X-ray crystallography were prepared by using the methods described in the synthetic procedure and mounted on a glass rod. Data collections were made on a Rigaku CCD diffractometer (Saturn 70) with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 70 Å). The structures were solved by using direct methods (SIR 97) and expanded using Fourier techniques. The final cycles of full-matrix least-squares refinements on F 2 were converged with unweighted and weighted agreement factors of R 1 = Σ∥F o| − |F c∥/Σ|F o| (I > 2.00σ(I) for R1 and all reflections for R), and wR 2 = [Σw(F c 2 − F c 2)2/Σw(F c 2)2]1/2 (all reflections). Neutral atom scattering factors were taken from Cromer and Waber. Anomalous dispersion effects were included in F calcd 30; Δf′ and Δf′′ were taken from Creagh and McAuley. The mass attenuation coefficients were taken from Creagh and Hubbell. All calculations were performed using the CrystalStructure crystallographic software package. Crystallographic data for 1o and 1c are summarized in Table . CCDC-729109 for 1o and CCDC-729108 for 1c contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Analysis

Single crystals of 1o and 1c for X-ray crystallography were prepared by using the methods described in the synthetic procedure and mounted on a glass rod. Data collections were made on a Rigaku CCD diffractometer (Saturn 70) with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71070 Å). The structures were solved by using direct methods (SIR 97) and expanded using Fourier techniques. The final cycles of full-matrix least-squares refinements on F 2 were converged with unweighted and weighted agreement factors of R 1 = Σ∥F o| - |F c∥/Σ|F o| (I > 2.00σ(I) for R1 and all reflections for R), and wR 2 = [Σw(F c 2 - F c 2)2/Σw(F c 2)2]1/2 (all reflections). Neutral atom scattering factors were taken from Cromer and Waber. Anomalous dispersion effects were included in F calcd 30; Δf' and Δf'' were taken from Creagh and McAuley. The mass attenuation coefficients were taken from Creagh and Hubbell. All calculations were performed using the CrystalStructure crystallographic software package. Crystallographic data for 1o and 1c are summarized in Table . CCDC-729109 for 1o and CCDC-729108 for 1c contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

elements.content: XRPD of 1o, 1c, 1o-UV, and 1c-vis were measured on a Rigaku RINT-2500HK diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at room temperature in the range 5° ≤ 2θ ≤ 25°, for which a well-grounded polycrystalline sample was put into a narrow diameter quartz glass tube.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Powder Diffraction (XRPD)

XRPD of 1o, 1c, 1o-UV, and 1c-vis were measured on a Rigaku RINT-2500HK diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at room temperature in the range 5° ≤ 2θ ≤ 25°, for which a well-grounded polycrystalline sample was put into a narrow diameter quartz glass tube.

elements.content: The open-ring isomer of diarylethene has two conformations with the aryl rings in mirror symmetry (parallel conformation) and C 2 symmetry (antiparallel conformation). According to the Woodward−Hoffmann rule, photoinduced electrocyclic reactions of 6π systems proceed in the conrotatory mode. The conrotatory photocyclization of diarylethene can proceed only from the antiparallel conformation. See:

The open-ring isomer of diarylethene has two conformations with the aryl rings in mirror symmetry (parallel conformation) and C 2 symmetry (antiparallel conformation). According to the Woodward-Hoffmann rule, photoinduced electrocyclic reactions of 6π systems proceed in the conrotatory mode. The conrotatory photocyclization of diarylethene can proceed only from the antiparallel conformation. See:

(a) Photochromic diarylethene ligand with two carboxylate groups (dae-o2−: open-ring isomer, dae-c2−: closed-ring isomer), (b) double-cuboidal [Mn4] single-molecule magnet, and (c) 1-D coordination assemblies of [Mn4] single-molecule magnets linked by the photochromic diarylethene ligands in the open- and closed-ring forms, 1o and 1c.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1         a (a) Photochromic diarylethene ligand with two carboxylate groups (dae-o2-: open-ring isomer, dae-c2-: closed-ring isomer), (b) double-cuboidal [Mn4] single-molecule magnet, and (c) 1-D coordination assemblies of [Mn4] single-molecule magnets linked by the photochromic diarylethene ligands in the open- and closed-ring forms, 1o and 1c.

cln_elements.content:
Proposed Photoswitching Mechanisms in the Photochromic 1-D SMM Chains<xref rid="sch2-fn1"></xref>

(a) Direct switching of superexchange interactions due to the change in the π-system of the diarylethene ligand (intrachain switching) and (b) indirect switching of through-space interactions due to the change in the geometrical structure of the diarylethene ligand (interchain switching), where the arrows indicate the magnetization of SMM aligned on an easy axis; in the case of interacted systems of (a) and (b) with exchange couplings J, fustian antiferromagnetically coupled features were for instance illustrated.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Proposed Photoswitching Mechanisms in the Photochromic 1-D SMM Chains      a (a) Direct switching of superexchange interactions due to the change in the π-system of the diarylethene ligand (intrachain switching) and (b) indirect switching of through-space interactions due to the change in the geometrical structure of the diarylethene ligand (interchain switching), where the arrows indicate the magnetization of SMM aligned on an easy axis; in the case of interacted systems of (a) and (b) with exchange couplings J, fustian antiferromagnetically coupled features were for instance illustrated.
